candidates.title: TestChainItem for simpler test data
candidates.body:
### Summary

This is an experiment based on this proposal https://hackmd.io/OQg34t0kRpeItZ1O0ygyrQ

It makes some chain operations generic over SignedActionHashed, so that a simpler more stripped down `ChainItem` trait can be used in its place. This lets us write tests with a simpler `TestChainItem` instead of a full `SignedActionHashed`. `ChainItem` only knows about sequence number, hash, and previous hash, which are the essential elements for the concept of a hash chain.

Genuinely looking for feedback on this approach. I hope to use it to write a bunch more chain-related tests for my work on Chain Head Coordination. But if this makes things harder to understand when actually reading the code, it may not be worth it.

PROS:
- Easy to directly construct test fixture data and write assertions on just what's needed
- Test data is easier to reason about since it is stripped down to the essentials (hashes are constructable and referenceable as single numbers now instead of a 39 byte array)
- Debug output is much more helpful and readable, since there is less noise
- Helps enforce that chain-related functions are only concerned with the chain structure, since other concerns are hidden away by the trait

CONS:
- More generics everywhere. This is mitigated by the use of default type params, but the actual definitions of structs involve a lot more generics now, especially due to the fact that `ChainItem` needs an associated `Hash` type.
- Possibility of monomorphism slowing down compilation/adding to bloat
    - To make things work a bit more smoothly, I had to provide `ChainItem` implementations for both `Action` and `SignedActionHashed`. I could strip this down to a single impl with some modifications, but as it stands now, this introduces a bit of monomorphism. However the extraneous monomorphisms may be removed during dead code elimination anyway.
    - If we can ensure that we have only one "production" implementation per trait using to this pattern, and ensure that any other implementations are test-only, then we should incur no monomorphism overhead cost.
- We're not directly testing the actual implementation that runs in production, which seems a little risky, but as long as our trait is implemented properly for both test and production structs, then the same logic will hold, and this seems easy enough to guarantee

### TODO:
- [ ] CHANGELOG(s) updated with appropriate info
- [ ] Just before pressing the merge button, ensure new entries to CHANGELOG(s) are still under the _UNRELEASED_ heading

candidates.title: Integrate shared secret
candidates.body:
### Summary

- CHANGELOG: **BREAKING CHANGE** `x_salsa20_poly1305_*` functions have been properly implemented. Any previous `KeyRef`s will no longer work. These new functions DO NOT work with legacy lair `v0.0.z`, you must use NEW lair `v0.y.z` (v0.2.0 as of this PR).
- We also bump sodoken to a version using [libsodium-sys-stable](https://crates.io/crates/libsodium-sys-stable) (instead of [libsodium-sys](https://crates.io/crates/libsodium-sys) which is no longer maintained) - I [double checked with the maintainer](https://github.com/jedisct1/libsodium-sys-stable/issues/8) to verify they are intending to continue maintaining it.
- Removes the last vestiges of crypto libraries other than sodoken.

### TODO:
- [x] publish lair / remove patch.crates-io
- [x] CHANGELOG(s) updated with appropriate info
- [ ] Just before pressing the merge button, ensure new entries to CHANGELOG(s) are still under the _UNRELEASED_ heading

candidates.title: bump rand version && required associated fixes
candidates.body:
### Summary

- bump rand version, which now requires getrandom crate for randomness
- make getrandom compatible with hdk by fetching randomness from host system
  - NOTE with the current implementation, calls to rand functions will error if they don't have `non_determinism: Permission::Allow` -- which could be what we want, but we could also go the other way and expose an undocumented host function that would always succeed.

candidates.title: Rate limiting types needed for HDK 0.1
candidates.body:
### Summary

Adds a generic type to Header variants which require a weight. The generic allows us to express Headers with weights, or Headers that are explicitly unweighed. The plan is that we can use the unweighed version of Header types to pass to the weigh callback, which will actually assign the weight. Doing this sidesteps the chicken-and-egg problem of weighing something which has a field that specifies its own weight, removing a determinism footgun.

This contains just the changes that will affect the HDK, mostly changes to integrity zome types with placeholder fields. Based on #1325, and contains #1412
